newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya shilling eases, central bank sees strength.
newsitem.headline: Kenya shilling eases, central bank sees strength.

text.p: The Kenyan shilling eased marginally against the dollar on Tuesday in range-bound trading and central bank officials said they expected it to appreciate.
The Central Bank of Kenya (CBK) posted a shilling mean rate of 54.93 against the dollar versus 54.94 on Monday, while versus the pound, it was posted at a mean rate of 88.57 from 89.43.
"The shilling is currently strong and we expect this strength to continue," said CBK Chief Economist Maurice Kanga.
"In fact, the shilling is threatening to appreciate further," Kanga told a news briefing in Nairobi.
The central bank said in a separate statement that the large shilling exchange rate movements associated with the major economic reforms of 1993 to 1994 were unlikely to be repeated.
At the height of financial chaos in Kenya in October 1994, the shilling traded at 83 versus the dollar.

Dealers have said that central bank interventions in recent weeks stopped the shilling from further gains, but the central bank said: "The shilling exchange rate will be left to be determined by the market forces."
Dealers said the shilling eased slightly on Tuesday on modest dollar inflows from exporters amid subdued demand.
"Whatever little demand there is has been spread over, so it's not coming in large enough quantities to upset the market," a dealer said.
They added that in the absence of fresh factors to move the market, the shilling would remain stable as trade was well-balanced.
"A stable shilling is in line with the central bank's objective to create a healthy investment climate boosted by a stable unit," another dealer said.
"Investors can actually plan for the long term with a stable shilling," a financial analyst said.
Local money market funding of a 1.25 billion shillings deficit from the treasury bill auction last week, pushed overnight rates up marginally.
The rates were quoted between 10-15 percent compared to below 10 percent on Monday.
